elements.content: Three novel inorganic–organic composite polyoxotungstates {[Ni(dap)2(H2O)]2[Ni(dap)2]2[Ni4(Hdap)2(α-B-HSiW9O34)2]}·7H2O (1), {[Ni(dap)2(H2O)]2[Ni(dap)2]2[Ni4(Hdap)2(α-B-HGeW9O34)2]}·6H2O (2), and {[Ni(dap)2(H2O)]2[Ni(dap)2]2[Ni4(Hdap)2(α-B-PW9O34)2]}·4H2O (3) (dap = 1,2-diaminopropane) have been hydrothermally synthesized and characterized by IR spectra, optical diffuse reflection spectroscopy, elemental analysis, thermogravimetric analysis, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Three polyoxotungstates all crystallize in the triclinic space group P1̅, with a = 13.3613(4) Å, b = 13.9821(4) Å, c = 17.0305(5) Å, α = 68.085(10)°, β = 71.179(11)°, γ = 87.876(14)°, Z = 1, R 1 = 0.0742, wR 2 = 0.1692 for 1, a = 13.338(3) Å, b = 13.978(3) Å, c = 17.049(3) Å, α = 68.159(6)°, β = 71.100(8)°, γ = 87.683(9)°, Z = 1, R 1 = 0.0499, wR 2 = 0.1061 for 2, and a = 13.3570(19) Å, b = 13.997(2) Å, c = 17.129(2) Å, α = 67.468(4)°, β = 71.986(5)°, γ = 88.698(6)°, Z = 1, R 1 = 0.0461, wR 2 = 0.1254 for 3. Three isostructural polyoxotungstates utilize the two-dimensional structures with inorganic–organic composite surfaces built up from tetra-NiII-substituted sandwich-type Keggin polyoxometalate building blocks and NiII-dap cation bridges, representing the first (4,4)-connected topological network in polyoxometalate chemistry. Magnetic susceptibility measurements indicate the occurrence of ferromagnetic coupling interactions within the NiII centers for 1 and 2.

elements.content: A two-dimensional (4,4)-connected network constructed from tetra-NiII-substituted Keggin sandwich-type polyoxometalate building units {[Ni(dap)2(H2O)]2[Ni(dap)2]2[Ni4(Hdap)2(α-B-H n XW9O34)2]} (n = 1, X = SiIV, GeIV; n = 0, X = PV) has been successfully made based on different lacunary polyoxoanions and nickel cations in the presence of 1,2-diaminopropane under hydrothermal conditions.

elements.content: The contemporary extensively increasing interest in the design and synthesis of inorganic–organic composite materials reflects their interesting properties, which endows them with applications in a wide range of fields such as catalysis, molecular magnetism, optics, and material science as well as surprising compositional variability, electronic versatility, and topological diversity. In the chemistry of polyoxometalates (POMs), recently, an important interest is focused on the design and preparation of novel inorganic–organic composite POMs with unexpected structures and properties. One of the effective approaches is to introduce some interesting transition-metal complexes (TMCs) acting as bridges or pendants into the framework of the inorganic POMs. Hitherto, the classical Keggin fragments have often been used as the candidates mainly because the charge density of the surface oxygen atoms can be increased either by reducing some of metal centers or by replacing higher-valent metal centers with lower-valent metal centers. In this way, some composite materials incorporating POM and TMC moieties have been already obtained. For instance, [Ni(phen)3][PMoVI 9MoV 3O40{Ni(phen)}2], [Ni(2,2′-bpy)3]1.5[PWVI 10WV 2O40Ni(2,2′-bpy)2(H2O)], [Ag6(PMo10V2O40)]·(CH3COOH), K2[{SiW11O39Cu(H2O)}{Cu2(bpy)2(H2O)2(μ-ox)}2], and [4,4′-H2bpy][Cu(4,4′-bpy)]2[HPCuMo11O39]. In general, most of the Keggin fragments that are used are often plenary or monovacant; in contrast, the composite materials constructed by trivacant Keggin fragments and TMC moieties remain less developed.,
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The contemporary extensively increasing interest in the design and synthesis of inorganic-organic composite materials reflects their interesting properties, which endows them with applications in a wide range of fields such as catalysis, molecular magnetism, optics, and material science as well as surprising compositional variability, electronic versatility, and topological diversity. In the chemistry of polyoxometalates (POMs), recently, an important interest is focused on the design and preparation of novel inorganic-organic composite POMs with unexpected structures and properties. One of the effective approaches is to introduce some interesting transition-metal complexes (TMCs) acting as bridges or pendants into the framework of the inorganic POMs. Hitherto, the classical Keggin fragments have often been used as the candidates mainly because the charge density of the surface oxygen atoms can be increased either by reducing some of metal centers or by replacing higher-valent metal centers with lower-valent metal centers. In this way, some composite materials incorporating POM and TMC moieties have been already obtained. For instance, [Ni(phen)3][PMoVI 9MoV 3O40{Ni(phen)}2], [Ni(2,2'-bpy)3]1.5[PWVI 10WV 2O40Ni(2,2'-bpy)2(H2O)], [Ag6(PMo10V2O40)]⋅(CH3COOH), K2[{SiW11O39Cu(H2O)}{Cu2(bpy)2(H2O)2(μ-ox)}2], and [4,4'-H2bpy][Cu(4,4'-bpy)]2[HPCuMo11O39]. In general, most of the Keggin fragments that are used are often plenary or monovacant; in contrast, the composite materials constructed by trivacant Keggin fragments and TMC moieties remain less developed.,

elements.content: The first tetra-CoII substituted inorganic sandwich-type POM [Co4(H2O)2(α-B-PW9O34)2]10− was reported by Weakley et al. in 1973, and to date, the sandwich-type POMs have been constructed from two trivacant Keggin [α-B-XW9O34] n− (X = PV/AsV/SiIV/GeIV) or Wells-Dawson [α-X2W15O56]12− (X = PV/AsV) fragments in a staggered fashion, in which four transition-metal (TM) cores have developed as a well-known subfamily in the TM substituted POMs (TMSPs). Their pertinent optical, electronic, thermal, magnetic, and catalytic performances have been extensively investigated. However, the synthesis and exploration of high-dimensional [(two-dimensional (2D)/three-dimensional (3D)] inorganic–organic composite structures constructed from sandwich-type TMSPs remain less developed hitherto, which offers us great interest and opportunities. To obtain the above-mentioned high-dimensional sandwich-type TMSPs with benign physical-chemical properties, we are exploiting this system under hydrothermal conditions based on the following considerations: (a) Available surface oxygen atoms on inorganic sandwich-type TMSPs provide a significant likelihood for derivation of high-dimensional architectures; (b) introduction of organic components can alter and tune inorganic TMSP microstructures, which may influence the structural constructions of products. During the course of our search, three isostructural 2D sandwich-type TMSPs, {[Ni(dap)2(H2O)]2[Ni(dap)2]2[Ni4(Hdap)2(α-B-HSiW9O34)2]}·7H2O (1), {[Ni(dap)2(H2O)]2[Ni(dap)2]2[Ni4(Hdap)2(α-B-HGeW9O34)2]}·6H2O (2), and {[Ni(dap)2(H2O)]2[Ni(dap)2]2[Ni4(Hdap)2(α-B-PW9O34)2]}·4H2O (3), (dap = 1,2-diaminopropane), were obtained, which remarkably differ from those known examples built only by inorganic sandwich-type TMSPs. As expected, the combination between sandwich-type POMs and NiII-organic cations results in novel networks, which will open extensively a potential field in TMSP chemistry. The common structural characteristic is that each {[Ni(dap)2(H2O)]2[Ni(dap)2]2[Ni4(Hdap)2(α-B-H n XW9O34)2]} (n = 1, X = SiIV/GeIV; n = 0, X = PV) subunit links to four adjacent identical ones through four W−O−Ni−O−W bridges, forming a 2D architecture with a (4,4)-connected topology. To the best of our knowledge, this kind of structure has been very rarely reported previously.

elements.content: Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed using a PE 2400 II elemental analyzer. IR spectra were obtained on an ABB Bomen MB 102 spectrometer with pressed KBr pellets in the range of 4000–400 cm−1. Optical diffuse reflection spectra were obtained with a Perkin-Elmer Lambda 900 UV–vis−near-IR spectrophotometer equipped with an integrating sphere and BaSO4 as reference at room temperature in the wavelength region of 2000–200 nm. Thermogravimetric analyses were performed on a Mettler TGA/SDTA851 thermal analyzer in flowing air atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 in the temperature region of 30–1000 °C. Variable temperature magnetic susceptibilities were carried out in the temperature range of 2–300 K with a Quantum Design MPMS-5 magnetometer. Experimental susceptibilities were corrected for diamagnetism of the constituent atoms by use of Pascal’s constants. K8[γ-SiW10O36]·12H2O (γ-SiW10), Na10[α-A-SiW9O34]·18H2O (α-A-SiW9), K8Na2[α-A-GeW9O34]·25H2O (α-A-GeW9), Na12P2W15O56·18H2O (P2W15), and Na9[α-A-PW9O34]·7H2O (α-A-PW9) were prepared by previously published procedures. All the other chemical reagents were commercially purchased and used without further purification.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Methods and Materials

Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed using a PE 2400 II elemental analyzer. IR spectra were obtained on an ABB Bomen MB 102 spectrometer with pressed KBr pellets in the range of 4000-400 cm-1. Optical diffuse reflection spectra were obtained with a Perkin-Elmer Lambda 900 UV-vis-near-IR spectrophotometer equipped with an integrating sphere and BaSO4 as reference at room temperature in the wavelength region of 2000-200 nm. Thermogravimetric analyses were performed on a Mettler TGA/SDTA851 thermal analyzer in flowing air atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 in the temperature region of 30-1000 °C. Variable temperature magnetic susceptibilities were carried out in the temperature range of 2-300 K with a Quantum Design MPMS-5 magnetometer. Experimental susceptibilities were corrected for diamagnetism of the constituent atoms by use of Pascal's constants. K8[γ-SiW10O36]⋅12H2O (γ-SiW10), Na10[α-A-SiW9O34]⋅18H2O (α-A-SiW9), K8Na2[α-A-GeW9O34]⋅25H2O (α-A-GeW9), Na12P2W15O56⋅18H2O (P2W15), and Na9[α-A-PW9O34]⋅7H2O (α-A-PW9) were prepared by previously published procedures. All the other chemical reagents were commercially purchased and used without further purification.

elements.content: A mixture of γ-SiW10(0.297 g, 0.11 mmol), NiCl2·6H2O (0.178 g, 0.750 mmol), dap (0.15 mL, 1.767 mmol), and H2O (5 mL, 278 mmol) was stirred for 1.5 h (the starting pH 6.7), sealed in a Teflon-lined steel autoclave (20 mL), kept at 100 °C for 5 days, and then cooled to room temperature (the end pH 5.8). Olivine prismatic crystals were obtained by filtration, washed with distilled water, and dried in air. Yield: ca. 70% (based on γ-SiW10). Anal. Calcd (%): C, 6.18; H, 2.11; N, 4.80. Found: C, 6.22; H, 2.04; N, 4.67. IR (KBr Pellet, cm−1): 3445(s), 3344(s), 3276(m), 2963(w), 2878(w), 1630(s), 1591(m), 1462(w), 1383(w), 1199(w), 1045(m), 981(s), 938(s), 875(s), 830(m), 784(s), 706(s), 540(m), 513(m).

elements.content: An olivine prism crystal with dimensions 0.50 × 0.10 × 0.10 mm3 for 1, 0.13 × 0.05 × 0.02 mm3 for 2, and 0.25 × 0.25 × 0.13 mm3 for 3 was stuck on a glass fiber, and intensity data were collected at 293 K on a RIGAKU Mercury 70 CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Cell constants and an orientation matrix for data collection were obtained from least-squares refinements of the setting angles in the range of 2.08 ≤ θ ≤ 27.48°. Routine Lorentz polarization and an empirical absorption correction were applied to intensity data. On the basis of systematic absences and statistics of intensity, their space groups were found to be P1̅. Their structures were determined, and the heavy atoms were found by direct methods using the SHELXTL-97 program package. The remaining atoms were found from successive full-matrix least-squares refinements on F 2 and Fourier syntheses. No hydrogen atoms associated with water molecules were located from the difference Fourier map. Positions of the hydrogen atoms attached to carbon and nitrogen atoms were geometrically placed. All hydrogen atoms were refined isotropically as a riding mode using the default SHELXTL parameters. For 1, of 17 615 reflections, 9651 unique reflections (R int = 0.0561) were considered observed [I > 2σ(I)]. The final cycle of refinement including atomic coordinates and the anisotropic thermal parameters (except for O4W−O6W, C3, C7−C9, C12, and C15) converged at R 1 = 0.0742 and wR 2 = 0.1692 [I > 2σ(I)]. For 2, of 21 810 reflections, 12 466 unique reflections (R int = 0.0345) were considered observed [I > 2σ(I)]. The final cycle of refinement including atomic coordinates and the anisotropic thermal parameters (except for O3W, O4W, C10, C11, and C12) converged at R 1 = 0.0499 and wR 2 = 0.1061 [I > 2σ(I)]. For 3, of 17 776 reflections, 9754 unique reflections (R int = 0.0361) were considered observed [I > 2σ(I)]. The final cycle of refinement including atomic coordinates and the anisotropic thermal parameters (except for C7−C9, C14, C15, and N10) converged at R 1 = 0.0462 and wR 2 = 0.1255 [I > 2σ(I)]. Crystallographic data and structure refinements for 1−3 are summarized in Table . Selected bond length ranges for 1−3 are given in Table . The CCDC numbers are allocated as 64277–64279 for 1−3, respectively.

Ot is the terminal oxygen atom combined with only one W atom; Ob(c) is the μ2-O atom shared by two W atoms (Ob atom shared by two W atoms of different W3O13 units; Oc atom shared by two W atoms from the same W3O13 unit); Oa is the μ4-O oxygen atom bound to a heteroatom Si, Ge, or P and three W atoms; ONi is the oxygen atom shared by W and Ni atoms.

Lacunary fragments (γ-SiW10, α-A-GeW9, P2W15) can be regarded as the bulky polydentate inorganic ligands that further coordinate to TMC cations, forming novel lacunary POM derivatives. However, it is difficult to design a rational synthetic route to make lacunary POM derivatives containing TMC cations by the conventional aqueous solution method at atmosphere pressure because lacunary fragments, TM cations, and organic ligands poorly dissolve in aqueous solution. Therefore, we used the hydrothermal method to explore the possibility of this system. Furthermore, the hydrothermal method has recently been proved to be an extremely effective method in making organic–inorganic composite solid materials. Hydrothermal conditions are able to make the reaction shift from the thermodynamic to the kinetic so that equilibrium phases are replaced by structurally more complicated metastable phases. In a specific hydrothermal process, many factors can influence the formation of crystal phases, such as initial reactants, initial concentrations, pH value, reaction time, and temperature. In our case, parallel experiments reveal that initial reactants greatly influence the structures of products.

Results and Discussion

Synthesis

Lacunary fragments (γ-SiW10, α-A-GeW9, P2W15) can be regarded as the bulky polydentate inorganic ligands that further coordinate to TMC cations, forming novel lacunary POM derivatives. However, it is difficult to design a rational synthetic route to make lacunary POM derivatives containing TMC cations by the conventional aqueous solution method at atmosphere pressure because lacunary fragments, TM cations, and organic ligands poorly dissolve in aqueous solution. Therefore, we used the hydrothermal method to explore the possibility of this system. Furthermore, the hydrothermal method has recently been proved to be an extremely effective method in making organic-inorganic composite solid materials. Hydrothermal conditions are able to make the reaction shift from the thermodynamic to the kinetic so that equilibrium phases are replaced by structurally more complicated metastable phases. In a specific hydrothermal process, many factors can influence the formation of crystal phases, such as initial reactants, initial concentrations, pH value, reaction time, and temperature. In our case, parallel experiments reveal that initial reactants greatly influence the structures of products.

elements.content: The successful syntheses of 1−3 were based on three different types of lacunary POM precursors. First, 1 was synthesized by the reaction of the metastable divacant Keggin precursor γ-SiW10 with NiCl2·6H2O in the presence of dap under mild hydrothermal conditions (100 °C). This indicated that the formation of 1 must experience the following reaction process: isomerization ([γ-SiW10O36]8− → [α-B-SiW9O34]10−), loss of the tungsten, metal incorporation, and polymerization. The reaction equation for 1 can be described as

Subsequently, when α-A-SiW9 replaced γ-SiW10, a hexa-NiII incorporated trivacant Keggin POM [Ni(dap)2]0.5[Ni6(dap)3(H2O)6(OH)3(α-B-SiW9O34)]·10H2O was formed (Table ). Also, the isomerization of [α-A-SiW9O34]10− → [α-B-SiW9O34]10− was observed. Moreover, the transformations between different types of silicotungstates in aqueous solution were systematically studied by Tézé et al. and well understood. Interaction of the metastable divacant silicotungstates with TM ions had led to some mono-, di-, and trisubstituted TMSP species. Since protons are consumed in this reaction, a slight increase of the pH value from 6.2 to 6.7 is expected. Furthermore, when the usage amount of dap decreased from 0.25 to 0.10 mL, a hexa-NiII incorporated trivacant Keggin POM [Ni6(dap)3(H2O)6(OH)3][α-B-GeW9O34]·H3O·4H2O, which is similar to [Ni(enMe)2][Ni6(μ3-OH)3(H2O)6(enMe)3(α-B-SiW9O34)]2·10H2O, was obtained. Although great efforts were made to produce analogous crystals based on α-A-PW9 unit, we failed and still obtained a hexa-NiII incorporated trivacant Keggin polyoxotungstate (POT) [Ni6(dap)2(H2O)8(OH)3][α-B-PW9O34]·7H2O. When using P2W15 in place of α-A-PW9, 3 was fortunately obtained and obviously experienced degradation ([P2W15O56]12− → [α-B-PW9O34]9−), metal incorporation and polymerization. The reaction equation for 3 is 6 [ P 2 W 15 O 56 ] 12 −   +   40 N i 2 + + 50 dap +   22 H 2 O = 5 { [ N i ( dap ) 2 ( H 2 O ) ] 2 [ Ni ( dap ) 2 ] 2 [ N i 4 ( Hdap ) 2 ( α - B -P W 9 O 34 ) 2 ] } + 2 P O 4 3 − + 14 H +     In this reaction, the decrease of the pH value from 9.6 to 8.2 is closely related to the formation of protons.

When using P2W15 in place of α-A-PW9, 3 was fortunately obtained and obviously experienced degradation ([P2W15O56]12- → [α-B-PW9O34]9-), metal incorporation and polymerization. elements.content: From the systematic investigation of synthetic conditions and reaction processes in the present system, it is necessary that the isomerization or degradation of POM precursors occurred in the formation of 1−3. However, when the trivacant Keggin fragments were chosen as initial materials, the formation tendency of hexa-NiII incorporated POTs was larger than that of sandwich-type POTs with 2D structures. To further explore the influence of other TM ions on the structural architectures in the present system, we extended the cations from Ni2+ to Mn2+, Fe2+, Co2+, and Cu2+. The results indicated that when Mn2+ and Co2+ ions were employed, no analogue was made but only amorphous powders formed. The reaction of Fe2+ with α-A-PW9 led to red octahedral crystals with poor quality that did not suit the data collection of single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The condition optimization is being performed to make good quality crystals. The reaction of Fe2+ with γ-SiW10 or α-A-GeW9 resulted in amorphous powders. When Cu2+ ions were introduced, whether in the γ-SiW10 system or in the α-A-GeW9 system, dark-green octa-CuII sandwiched POTs [Cu(dap)(H2O)3]2[Cu8(dap)4(H2O)2(α-B-SiW9O34)2]·6H2O and H4[Cu8(dap)4(H2O)2(α-B-GeW9O34)2]·13H2O were always obtained. However, the reaction of Cu2+ with α-A-PW9 resulted in a one-dimensional (1D) chain copperII-monosubstituted Keggin POT [Cu (dap)2]2{[Cu(dap)2]2[Cu(dap)2][α-PCuW11O39]2}. These results reveal that the nature of TM ions plays a significant role in the construction of structural diversity. Work on octa-CuII sandwiched POTs is in progress, and the related results will be discussed elsewhere.

elements.content: IR spectra of 1–3 display characteristic vibration patterns derived from the Keggin framework () in 700–1100 cm−1. Four characteristic bands attributable to ν(W−Ot), ν(X−Oa) (X = Si/Ge/P), ν(W−Ob), and ν(W−Oc), appear at 938, 875, 786, and 706 cm−1 for 1, 939, 835, 770, and 694 cm−1 for 2, and 936, 1035, 886, and 777 cm−1 for 3, respectively. The ν(X−Oa) modes, observed as a single signal in the region 820–1040 cm−1 for 1−3, correlate very well to the X−Oa distances; that is, the higher ν(X−Oa) vibration frequency corresponds to the shorter X−Oa bond lengths, and on the contrary, the lower ν(X−Oa) vibration frequency corresponds to the longer X−Oa bond lengths (Table ). Moreover, a close examination of infrared spectra of 1–3 reveals that ν(W−Ot) vibration frequencies have red-shifts, which may stem from the stronger interactions between Ni-dap cations and terminal oxygen atoms. In addition, the stretching bands of -OH, -NH2, and -CH2 groups are observed at 3420–3450 cm−1, 3120–3350 cm−1, and 2950–3000 cm−1, respectively. The bending vibration bands of -NH2 and -CH2 groups also appear at 1590–1630 cm−1 and 1455–1465 cm−1, respectively. The occurrence of these resonance signals confirms the presence of organic amine groups, which are in good agreement with the single-crystal structural analyses.

IR Spectra

IR spectra of 1-3 display characteristic vibration patterns derived from the Keggin framework () in 700-1100 cm-1. Four characteristic bands attributable to ν(W-Ot), ν(X-Oa) (X = Si/Ge/P), ν(W-Ob), and ν(W-Oc), appear at 938, 875, 786, and 706 cm-1 for 1, 939, 835, 770, and 694 cm-1 for 2, and 936, 1035, 886, and 777 cm-1 for 3, respectively. The ν(X-Oa) modes, observed as a single signal in the region 820-1040 cm-1 for 1-3, correlate very well to the X-Oa distances; that is, the higher ν(X-Oa) vibration frequency corresponds to the shorter X-Oa bond lengths, and on the contrary, the lower ν(X-Oa) vibration frequency corresponds to the longer X-Oa bond lengths (Table ). Moreover, a close examination of infrared spectra of 1-3 reveals that ν(W-Ot) vibration frequencies have red-shifts, which may stem from the stronger interactions between Ni-dap cations and terminal oxygen atoms. In addition, the stretching bands of -OH, -NH2, and -CH2 groups are observed at 3420-3450 cm-1, 3120-3350 cm-1, and 2950-3000 cm-1, respectively. The bending vibration bands of -NH2 and -CH2 groups also appear at 1590-1630 cm-1 and 1455-1465 cm-1, respectively. The occurrence of these resonance signals confirms the presence of organic amine groups, which are in good agreement with the single-crystal structural analyses.

elements.content: Single-crystal structural analyses reveal that 1–3 are almost isostructural and crystallize in the same triclinic space group P1̅ (Figure and ). Therefore, only the structure of 1 is described in detail. Their common structural feature is best described as a 2D network constructed from {[Ni(dap)2(H2O)]2[Ni(dap)2]2[Ni4(Hdap)2(α-B-HXW9O34)2]} (n = 1, X = SiIV, GeIV; n = 0, X = PV) building units. This kind of structure construction is mainly governed by the [Ni(dap)2]2+ functionality. The structural unit of 1 consists of a hexa-supporting subunit {[Ni(dap)2(H2O)]2[Ni(dap)2]2[Ni4(Hdap)2(α-B-HSiW9O34)2]} and seven lattice–water molecules. Each subunit links to four adjacent same ones through two [Ni1(dap)2]2+ and two [Ni2(dap)2]2+ bridges, forming a 2D architecture with (4,4)-network topology in the ac plane (Figure and ), which obviously differ from these known examples only containing inorganic sandwich-type TMSPs. Except for two 2D trivacant Keggin POTs CsNa2[{Sn(CH3)2}3(H2O)4(β-XW9O33)]·7H2O (X = AsIII/SbIII) made by the conventional aqueous solution method and a 2D tetra-TM sandwiched POT recently reported by our group under hydrothermal conditions, to our knowledge, 1−3 represent the rare (4,4)-topological network in sandwich-type POM chemistry.

Crystal Structures

Single-crystal structural analyses reveal that 1-3 are almost isostructural and crystallize in the same triclinic space group P1̅ (Figure  and ). Therefore, only the structure of 1 is described in detail. Their common structural feature is best described as a 2D network constructed from {[Ni(dap)2(H2O)]2[Ni(dap)2]2[Ni4(Hdap)2(α-B-HXW9O34)2]} (n = 1, X = SiIV, GeIV; n = 0, X = PV) building units. This kind of structure construction is mainly governed by the [Ni(dap)2]2+ functionality. The structural unit of 1 consists of a hexa-supporting subunit {[Ni(dap)2(H2O)]2[Ni(dap)2]2[Ni4(Hdap)2(α-B-HSiW9O34)2]} and seven lattice-water molecules. Each subunit links to four adjacent same ones through two [Ni1(dap)2]2+ and two [Ni2(dap)2]2+ bridges, forming a 2D architecture with (4,4)-network topology in the ac plane (Figure  and ), which obviously differ from these known examples only containing inorganic sandwich-type TMSPs. Except for two 2D trivacant Keggin POTs CsNa2[{Sn(CH3)2}3(H2O)4(β-XW9O33)]⋅7H2O (X = AsIII/SbIII) made by the conventional aqueous solution method and a 2D tetra-TM sandwiched POT recently reported by our group under hydrothermal conditions, to our knowledge, 1-3 represent the rare (4,4)-topological network in sandwich-type POM chemistry.

elements.content: As shown in Figure a, the centrosymmetric {[Ni(dap)2(H2O)]2[Ni(dap)2]2[Ni4(Hdap)2(α-B-HSiW9O34)2]} subunit consists of a tetra-NiII sandwiched [Ni4(Hdap)2(α-B-HSi W9O34)2]8− core, two pendent [Ni3(dap)(H2O)3]2+ cations, and two kinds of unique [Ni(dap)2]2+ cations, [Ni1(dap)2]2+ and [Ni2(dap)2]2+. Alternatively, this subunit can also be viewed as a combination of two half-units {[Ni(dap)2(H2O)][Ni(Hdap)2][Ni2(dap)(α-B-HSiW9O34)]} related by an inversion center (1,0,1). The [Ni1(dap)2]2+/[Ni2(dap)2]2+ ions located on the special sites with atomic coordinates of (0,0,1/2) and (1/2,0,1) lead to an occupancy of 50% for Ni1 and Ni2 atoms, respectively. The bridging [Ni1(dap)2]2+ and [Ni2(dap)2]2+ ions have octahedral geometries, in which four N atoms from two dap ligands build the basal plane [Ni−N: 2.057(4)–2.197(3) Å] and two terminal oxygen atoms from adjacent two POM fragments occupy two axial positions [Ni−O: 2.080(4)–2.100(3) Å]. Moreover, the pendent [Ni3(dap)(H2O)3]2+ cation is also embedded in an octahedral coordination environment defined by four N atoms from two dap ligands, one water oxygen atom, and one terminal oxygen atom from the POM backbone with Ni−N, Ni−OW, and Ni−OPOM distances of 1.931(3)–2.105(7) Å, 2.129(7) Å and 2.170(3) Å, respectively. The dimer [Ni4(Hdap)2(α-B-HSiW9O34)2]8− is constructed from two trivacant Keggin [α-B-SiW9O34]10− moieties in a staggered fashion linked via a rhomb-like Ni4O14N2 group resulting in a sandwich-type assembly. Specifically, the Ni4O14N2 group is combined with two [α-B-SiW9O34]10− moieties via exposed 14 bridging O atoms from lacunae of two [α-B-SiW9O34]10- units (two μ4-O from one SiO4 groups and 12 μ2-O from 12 WO6 groups). Both Ni4 and Ni5 ions in the sandwich belt adopt distorted octahedral coordination environments with Ni−O and Ni−N distances of 2.032(3)–2.136(3) Å and 2.123(5) Å. Additionally, to determine the possible positions of four protons, bond valence sum (BVS) calculations of all oxygen atoms from two [α-B-SiW9O34]10− moieties in 1 have been performed (). The BVS values of O12/O12A atoms are significantly lower (1.32), indicative of possible positions binding protons. According to the reaction environment, two pendent dap ligands on Ni4O14N2 group should be monoprotonated. Therefore, the molecular formula of 1 is described as {[Ni(dap)2(H2O)]2[Ni(dap)2]2[Ni4(Hdap)2(α-B-HSiW9O34)2]}.

elements.content: It is noteworthy that the tetra-NiII sandwiched [Ni4(Hdap)2(α-B-HSiW9O34)2]8− fragment in 1 is somewhat distinct from the reported classical inorganic [M4(H2O)2(α-B-SiW9O34)2]12− polyoxoanion (M = Mn2+, Cu2+, and Zn2+). Obviously, two monoprotonated dap ligands in 1 are substituted for two coordination–water molecules at two unshared MO6 vertices from the rhomb-like M4O16 group in [M4(H2O)2(α-B-SiW9O34)2]12− (Figure b) leading to the inorganic–organic composite polyoxoanion [Ni4(Hdap)2(α-B-HSiW9O34)2]8−. The substitution of two dap ligands for two coordination–water molecules met our expectation, and at the same time, this provided the possibility of using the rigid ligand (4,4′-bipyridine) in place of dap to construct novel extended structures in our ongoing work.

The substitution of two dap ligands for two coordination-water molecules met our expectation, and at the same time, this provided the possibility of using the rigid ligand (4,4'-bipyridine) in place of dap to construct novel extended structures in our ongoing work.

elements.content: Additionally, the α-junction has been seen at the site of metal incorporation in several sandwich-type POMs, for example, in the [Ni3Na(H2O)2(α-B-PW9O34)2]11− anion (Figure a); however, the sandwich-type [Ni4(Hdap)2(α-B-HSiW9O34)2]8− fragment illustrates a structural type of β-junction at the site of metal incorporation (Figure b). This type of junction was first reported by Weakley in 1973. The difference of the corner-edge alignment feature between α-junction and β-junction at the site of metal incorporation is shown in Figure . Compare the [Ni4(Hdap)2(α-B-HSiW9O34)2]8− fragment in 1 with the [Ni3Na(H2O)2(α-B-PW9O34)2]11− anion; the interesting thing is that the linkage of the [Ni4(Hdap)2(α-B-HSiW9O34)2]8− fragment has two β-junctions, while the linkage in [Ni3Na(H2O)2(α-B-PW9O34)2]11− anion involves two types of junctions, α-junction involving three Ni2+ ions and β-junction involving one Na+ and two Ni2+ ions. This observation is consistent with that of FeIII-substituted Dawson sandwich compounds and a double-sandwich-type MnII-substituted POM. For example, the tetra-FeIII-substituted [Fe2(FeH2O)2(P2W15O56)2]12− anion has two β-junctions, the di-FeIII-substituted [Fe2(NaH2O)2(P2W15O56)2]16− anion has two α-junctions, and the tri-FeIII-substituted [Fe2(FeH2O)(NaH2O)(P2W15O56)2]14− anion has one β-junction and one α-junction. The prevalence of β-junction over α-junction in sandwich-type POMs is in contrast to the known relative thermodynamic stability exhibited by α and β isomers (for example, Baker-Figgis isomers) of the parent Keggin structure. The most likely explanation for the prevalence of β-junctions in sandwich-type POMs is that the repulsion present between water ligands (here is dap ligands) coordinated to external metals and bridging O atoms bonded to the neighboring tungsten atoms of two [α-XW9O34] n− units dominates the small energetic differences between the Baker-Figgis isomers.

elements.content: The most intriguing beautiful feature of 1, 2, and 3 is that they facilitate unique 2D networks in the ac plane (Figure ). Although the inorganic–organic composite 2D network structures based on monovacant Keggin polyoxoanions and TMCs were reported, to our knowledge, 1, 2 and 3 represent the rare 2D structure containing trivacant Keggin polyoxoanions and TMCs in sandwich-type subfamily of POM chemistry. From the topological point of view, if the {[Ni(dap)2(H2O)]2Ni(dap)2}2[Ni4(Hdap)2(α-B-H n XW9O34)2]} units are viewed as four-connected nodes, the structure possesses a 2D (4,4)-network topology (Figure ). Therefore, the successful syntheses of 1, 2 and 3 indicate a new guidance for the development of a coordination network and the discovery of new topology in POM chemistry. In addition, taking into account strong hydrogen bonding interactions between hybrid polyoxo-anions and water molecules, the 3D supramolecular structures are generated through N−H···O hydrogen bonds with N···O distances of 2.984(5)–3.307(4) Å for 1, 2.971(15)–3.289(15) Å for 2, and 2.963(13)–3.408(19) Å for 3, respectively.

elements.content: Since first ferromagnetic POM containing the magnetically interesting CoII element was reported by Coronado et al. in 1992, great efforts have been devoted to this field. To investigate magnetic properties of 1 and 2, magnetic susceptibilities were performed on polycrystalline samples in the temperature range 2–300 K at an applied field of 5 kOe. The thermal variations of the χM and χM T for 1 and 2 display similar magnetic features, which are in good agreement with their isostructural characteristics (Figure ). The temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibility (χM) shows a constant value of 0.033 emu mol−1 for 1 and 0.035 emu mol−1 for 2 with a slight increase from 300 to 150 K. This tendency becomes more pronounced below 150 K, leading to an exponential increase between 50 and 2 K. Finally, a sharp increase reaches 13.32 emu mol−1 for 1 and 12.12 emu mol−1 for 2 at 2 K, respectively. In contrast, the χM T product increases from 9.77 emu mol−1 K and 9.94 emu mol−1 K at 300 K to reach a maximum of 40.29 emu mol−1 K at 12 K for 1 and 36.40 emu mol−1 K at 11 K for 2, respectively. Further decreasing the temperature leads to a decrease of the χM T product, which takes the value of 26.50 emu mol−1 K for 1 and 24.18 emu mol−1 K for 2 at 2 K, respectively. At high temperature (T > 150 K), the magnetic susceptibility data are well described by Curie–Weiss expressions with C = 7.39 emu mol−1 K mol, θ = 82.93 K for 1 and C = 7.78 emu mol−1 K mol, θ = 72.01 K for 2, respectively (). These behaviors agree with the presence of the relatively strong ferromagnetic exchange interactions between adjacent NiII centers mediated by the oxygen bridges. Additionally, the sudden decline of the χm T curve below 12 K for 1 and 11 K for 2 may be attributed to the contribution of the zero-field-splitting (ZFS) effects in the ground-state of the NiII cations. It is noteworthy that previous work has shown that the behavior of χM T at very low temperature is related to an anisotropic coupling of the NiII ions inside the cluster rather than to a mean field correction.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

Since first ferromagnetic POM containing the magnetically interesting CoII element was reported by Coronado et al. in 1992, great efforts have been devoted to this field. To investigate magnetic properties of 1 and 2, magnetic susceptibilities were performed on polycrystalline samples in the temperature range 2-300 K at an applied field of 5 kOe. The thermal variations of the χM and χM T for 1 and 2 display similar magnetic features, which are in good agreement with their isostructural characteristics (Figure ). The temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibility (χM) shows a constant value of 0.033 emu mol-1 for 1 and 0.035 emu mol-1 for 2 with a slight increase from 300 to 150 K. This tendency becomes more pronounced below 150 K, leading to an exponential increase between 50 and 2 K. Finally, a sharp increase reaches 13.32 emu mol-1 for 1 and 12.12 emu mol-1 for 2 at 2 K, respectively. In contrast, the χM T product increases from 9.77 emu mol-1 K and 9.94 emu mol-1 K at 300 K to reach a maximum of 40.29 emu mol-1 K at 12 K for 1 and 36.40 emu mol-1 K at 11 K for 2, respectively. Further decreasing the temperature leads to a decrease of the χM T product, which takes the value of 26.50 emu mol-1 K for 1 and 24.18 emu mol-1 K for 2 at 2 K, respectively. At high temperature (T > 150 K), the magnetic susceptibility data are well described by Curie-Weiss expressions with C = 7.39 emu mol-1 K mol, θ = 82.93 K for 1 and C = 7.78 emu mol-1 K mol, θ = 72.01 K for 2, respectively (). These behaviors agree with the presence of the relatively strong ferromagnetic exchange interactions between adjacent NiII centers mediated by the oxygen bridges. Additionally, the sudden decline of the χm T curve below 12 K for 1 and 11 K for 2 may be attributed to the contribution of the zero-field-splitting (ZFS) effects in the ground-state of the NiII cations. It is noteworthy that previous work has shown that the behavior of χM T at very low temperature is related to an anisotropic coupling of the NiII ions inside the cluster rather than to a mean field correction.

elements.content: Considering the cluster structure and connection motif of magnetic centers in 1 and 2, the ferromagnetic exchange interactions mainly occur in the rhomb-like tetranuclear Ni4O14N2 core in the sandwich belt built by Ni4, Ni4A, Ni5, and Ni5A cores. Such ferromagnetic exchange interactions have been previously observed for tetra-NiII clusters in K6Na4[Ni4(H2O)2(α-B-PW9O34)2]·24H2O and [Ni4(μ3-OH)2(H2O)6(ntp)2]·2H2O (H3ntp = N(CH2CH2COOH)3). Moreover, the ferromagnetic exchange interactions in a cubane Ni4O4 cluster unit in Cs2[H2PW9Ni4O34(OH)3(H2O)6]·5H2O have been investigated by Kortz et al. The trimeric NiII cluster units in the lacunary POM fragments, such as [Ni3Na(H2O)2(AsW9O34)2] and [Ni3(H2O)3(PW10O39)H2O] also indicate the occurrence of the ferromagnetic exchange interactions. Their magnetic properties are largely due to the interactions between 3 A 2 NiII ions. For 1 and 2, the Ni−O−Ni pairwise interactions between the spins (S = 1) are mostly transmitted through the μ3-O and μ4-O bridges. In view of the rhomb-like tetranuclear Ni4O14N2 core, the ferromagnetic exchange interactions are expected in this system. As a matter of fact, all the Ni−O−Ni bond angles are in the range of 94.3(1)–96.3(1)° for 1 and 97.7(3)–98.3(3)° for 2, which are in the range where the Ni−Ni ferromagnetic exchange interactions dominate (90 ± 14°) by the d x2−y2 orbitals on NiII cations via the p orbitals on the bridging oxygen atoms, and the steady increase in χm T on decreasing temperature confirms this point.

elements.content: Three novel 2D POTs {[Ni(dap)2(H2O)]2[Ni(dap)2]2[Ni4(Hdap)2(α-B-HSiW9O34)2]}·7H2O (1), {[Ni(dap)2(H2O)]2[Ni(dap)2]2[Ni4(Hdap)2(α-B-HGeW9O34)2]}·6H2O (2), and {[Ni(dap)2(H2O)]2[Ni(dap)2]2[Ni4(Hdap)2(α-B-PW9O34)2]}·4H2O (3) have been hydrothermally synthesized and not prepared by the conventional aqueous solution method at atmospheric pressure. Their structures represent the rare 2D (4,4)-connected topological network in sandwich-type POM chemistry. Optical absorption spectra of 1–3 indicate the presence of optical band gaps and the nature of semiconductivity. Magnetic properties of 1 and 2 indicate ferromagnetic coupling interactions within the NiII centers. On the other hand, these findings presented here not only enrich the diversity of sandwich-type TMSP chemistry, but also provide an effective way for making novel and unique inorganic–organic composite TMSPs. Further work in this area will be focused on making other TMSPs or larger metal cluster aggregates with high-dimensional structures and good magnetic properties.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Three novel 2D POTs {[Ni(dap)2(H2O)]2[Ni(dap)2]2[Ni4(Hdap)2(α-B-HSiW9O34)2]}⋅7H2O (1), {[Ni(dap)2(H2O)]2[Ni(dap)2]2[Ni4(Hdap)2(α-B-HGeW9O34)2]}⋅6H2O (2), and {[Ni(dap)2(H2O)]2[Ni(dap)2]2[Ni4(Hdap)2(α-B-PW9O34)2]}⋅4H2O (3) have been hydrothermally synthesized and not prepared by the conventional aqueous solution method at atmospheric pressure. Their structures represent the rare 2D (4,4)-connected topological network in sandwich-type POM chemistry. Optical absorption spectra of 1-3 indicate the presence of optical band gaps and the nature of semiconductivity. Magnetic properties of 1 and 2 indicate ferromagnetic coupling interactions within the NiII centers. On the other hand, these findings presented here not only enrich the diversity of sandwich-type TMSP chemistry, but also provide an effective way for making novel and unique inorganic-organic composite TMSPs. Further work in this area will be focused on making other TMSPs or larger metal cluster aggregates with high-dimensional structures and good magnetic properties.

elements.content: Representations of IR spectra, optical diffuse reflection spectra, thermogravimetric analyses, ball-and-stick representations of 1−3 plots of the inverse magnetic susceptibility versus temperature for 1 and 2, and X-ray crystallographic files in CIF format. The information is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

cln_elements.content:
A mixture of γ-SiW10(0.297 g, 0.11 mmol), NiCl2·6H2O (0.178 g, 0.750 mmol), dap (0.15 mL, 1.767 mmol), and H2O (5 mL, 278 mmol) was stirred for 1.5 h (the starting pH 6.7), sealed in a Teflon-lined steel autoclave (20 mL), kept at 100 °C for 5 days, and then cooled to room temperature (the end pH 5.8). Olivine prismatic crystals were obtained by filtration, washed with distilled water, and dried in air. Yield: ca. 70% (based on γ-SiW10). Anal. Calcd (%): C, 6.18; H, 2.11; N, 4.80. Found: C, 6.22; H, 2.04; N, 4.67. IR (KBr Pellet, cm−1): 3445(s), 3344(s), 3276(m), 2963(w), 2878(w), 1630(s), 1591(m), 1462(w), 1383(w), 1199(w), 1045(m), 981(s), 938(s), 875(s), 830(m), 784(s), 706(s), 540(m), 513(m).

Synthesis of {[Ni(dap)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)]<sub>2</sub>[Ni(dap)<sub>2</sub>]<sub>2</sub>[Ni<sub>4</sub>(Hdap)<sub>2</sub>(α-B-HGeW<sub>9</sub>O<sub>34</sub>)<sub>2</sub>]}·6H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>2</bold>)

2 was isolated by reaction of α-A-GeW9 (0.246 g, 0.08 mmol), NiCl2·6H2O (0.237 g, 1.0 mmol), dap (0.25 mL, 2.945 mmol), and H2O (8 mL, 444 mmol) in an analogous way to 1 at 100 °C (the starting/end pH 6.2/6.7). Yield: ca. 55% (based on α-A-GeW9). Anal. Calcd (%): C, 6.11; H, 2.05; N, 4.75. Found: C, 6.04; H, 1.98; N, 4.82. IR (KBr Pellet, cm−1): 3447(s), 3310(s), 3258(m), 2965(w), 1630(s), 1458 (m), 1353(w), 1199(w), 1044(m), 939(s), 831(s), 769(s), 702(s), 517(m), 460(m).

Synthesis of {[Ni(dap)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)]<sub>2</sub>[Ni(dap)<sub>2</sub>]<sub>2</sub>[Ni<sub>4</sub>(Hdap)<sub>2</sub>(α-B-PW<sub>9</sub>O<sub>34</sub>)<sub>2</sub>]}·4H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>3</bold>)

P2W15 (0.216 g, 0.05 mmol), NiCl2·6H2O (0.094 g, 0.395 mmol), dap (0.10 mL, 1.178 mmol) were successively dissolved in H2O (5 mL, 278 mmol). The resulting mixture was adjusted to pH = 9.6 using HCl (0.1 mol L−1), transferred to a Teflon-lined steel autoclave (20 mL) after stirring for 1.5 h, kept at 120 °C for 5 days, and then cooled to room temperature (the end pH 8.2). Olivine prismatic crystals were obtained by filtration, washed with distilled water, and dried in air. Yield: ca. 31% (based on P2W15). Anal. Calcd (%): C, 6.23; H, 1.99; N, 4.85. Found: C, 6.17; H, 2.04; N, 4.79. IR (KBr Pellet, cm−1): 3445(s), 3344(s), 3276(m), 2963(w), 2878(w), 1630(s), 1591(m), 1462(w), 1383(w), 1199(w), 1045(m), 981(s), 938(s), 875(s), 830(m), 784(s), 706(s), 540(m), 513(m).

cln_elements.content:
Three novel inorganic–organic composite polyoxotungstates {[Ni(dap)2(H2O)]2[Ni(dap)2]2[Ni4(Hdap)2(α-B-HSiW9O34)2]}·7H2O (1), {[Ni(dap)2(H2O)]2[Ni(dap)2]2[Ni4(Hdap)2(α-B-HGeW9O34)2]}·6H2O (2), and {[Ni(dap)2(H2O)]2[Ni(dap)2]2[Ni4(Hdap)2(α-B-PW9O34)2]}·4H2O (3) (dap = 1,2-diaminopropane) have been hydrothermally synthesized and characterized by IR spectra, optical diffuse reflection spectroscopy, elemental analysis, thermogravimetric analysis, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Three polyoxotungstates all crystallize in the triclinic space group P1̅, with a = 13.3613(4) Å, b = 13.9821(4) Å, c = 17.0305(5) Å, α = 68.085(10)°, β = 71.179(11)°, γ = 87.876(14)°, Z = 1, R 1 = 0.0742, wR 2 = 0.1692 for 1, a = 13.338(3) Å, b = 13.978(3) Å, c = 17.049(3) Å, α = 68.159(6)°, β = 71.100(8)°, γ = 87.683(9)°, Z = 1, R 1 = 0.0499, wR 2 = 0.1061 for 2, and a = 13.3570(19) Å, b = 13.997(2) Å, c = 17.129(2) Å, α = 67.468(4)°, β = 71.986(5)°, γ = 88.698(6)°, Z = 1, R 1 = 0.0461, wR 2 = 0.1254 for 3. Three isostructural polyoxotungstates utilize the two-dimensional structures with inorganic–organic composite surfaces built up from tetra-NiII-substituted sandwich-type Keggin polyoxometalate building blocks and NiII-dap cation bridges, representing the first (4,4)-connected topological network in polyoxometalate chemistry. Magnetic susceptibility measurements indicate the occurrence of ferromagnetic coupling interactions within the NiII centers for 1 and 2.

Magnetic Properties

Since first ferromagnetic POM containing the magnetically interesting CoII element was reported by Coronado et al. in 1992, great efforts have been devoted to this field. To investigate magnetic properties of 1 and 2, magnetic susceptibilities were performed on polycrystalline samples in the temperature range 2–300 K at an applied field of 5 kOe. The thermal variations of the χM and χM T for 1 and 2 display similar magnetic features, which are in good agreement with their isostructural characteristics (Figure ). The temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibility (χM) shows a constant value of 0.033 emu mol−1 for 1 and 0.035 emu mol−1 for 2 with a slight increase from 300 to 150 K. This tendency becomes more pronounced below 150 K, leading to an exponential increase between 50 and 2 K. Finally, a sharp increase reaches 13.32 emu mol−1 for 1 and 12.12 emu mol−1 for 2 at 2 K, respectively. In contrast, the χM T product increases from 9.77 emu mol−1 K and 9.94 emu mol−1 K at 300 K to reach a maximum of 40.29 emu mol−1 K at 12 K for 1 and 36.40 emu mol−1 K at 11 K for 2, respectively. Further decreasing the temperature leads to a decrease of the χM T product, which takes the value of 26.50 emu mol−1 K for 1 and 24.18 emu mol−1 K for 2 at 2 K, respectively. At high temperature (T > 150 K), the magnetic susceptibility data are well described by Curie–Weiss expressions with C = 7.39 emu mol−1 K mol, θ = 82.93 K for 1 and C = 7.78 emu mol−1 K mol, θ = 72.01 K for 2, respectively (). These behaviors agree with the presence of the relatively strong ferromagnetic exchange interactions between adjacent NiII centers mediated by the oxygen bridges. Additionally, the sudden decline of the χm T curve below 12 K for 1 and 11 K for 2 may be attributed to the contribution of the zero-field-splitting (ZFS) effects in the ground-state of the NiII cations. It is noteworthy that previous work has shown that the behavior of χM T at very low temperature is related to an anisotropic coupling of the NiII ions inside the cluster rather than to a mean field correction.

cln_elements.content: (a) Polyhedral and ball-and-stick illustration for 1. The atoms with the suffix A are generated by the symmetry operation: x, y, 1 + z for Ni1A; –1 + x, y, z for Ni2A; −x, −y, 2 − z for Ni3A. (b) The rhomb-like Ni4O14N2 group sandwiched by two trivacant [α-B-SiW9O34]10- Keggin fragments in an staggered fashion in 1 and atoms with the suffix A are generated by the symmetry operation: 2 − x, −y, 2 − z for Ni4A; 2 − x, −y, 2 − z for Ni5A. The solvent–water molecules and hydrogen atoms attached to carbon and nitrogen atoms were omitted for clarity.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Polyhedral and ball-and-stick illustration for 1. The atoms with the suffix A are generated by the symmetry operation: x, y, 1 + z for Ni1A; -1 + x, y, z for Ni2A; -x, -y, 2 - z for Ni3A. (b) The rhomb-like Ni4O14N2 group sandwiched by two trivacant [α-B-SiW9O34]10- Keggin fragments in an staggered fashion in 1 and atoms with the suffix A are generated by the symmetry operation: 2 - x, -y, 2 - z for Ni4A; 2 - x, -y, 2 - z for Ni5A. The solvent-water molecules and hydrogen atoms attached to carbon and nitrogen atoms were omitted for clarity.

cln_elements.content: The 2D network in the crystallographic ac plane in 1. The solvent–water molecules, hydrogen atoms, and [Ni3(dap)2(H2O)]2+ cations were omitted for clarity.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  The 2D network in the crystallographic ac plane in 1. The solvent-water molecules, hydrogen atoms, and [Ni3(dap)2(H2O)]2+ cations were omitted for clarity.

cln_elements.content: (a) Polyhedral and ball-and-stick representation for the [Ni3Na(H2O)2(α-B-PW9O34)2]11− anion showing the α-junction at the site of metal incorporation. (b) Polyhedral representation for the [Ni4(Hdap)2(α-B-HSiW9O34)2]8− fragment in 1 exhibiting the β-junction at the site of metal incorporation. The red elliptical regions reveal the difference of corner-edge alignment feature between the α-junction and the β-junction at the site of metal incorporation. The carbon and nitrogen atoms in b were omitted for clarity.
